verses.text: Call now, is there anyone who will answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?
verses.comment: Eliphaz questions Job's reliance on divine help, referencing spiritual beings; implies help is ultimately found in God alone, anticipating later understanding of intercession (see Job 16:20-21).

verses.text: Surely resentment kills the fool, and jealousy slays the simple.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the spiritual dangers of resentment and envy. Consistent with NT teaching on the heart's condition (James 3:16).

verses.text: I myself have seen a fool taking root, but suddenly his home was cursed.
verses.comment: Refers to the fleeting prosperity of the wicked, commonly referenced in both Psalms and Proverbs.

verses.text: His children are far from safety; they are crushed at the gate, and there is no one to deliver them.
verses.comment: The gate was the place of justice. Loss at the gate alludes to eventual judgment and vulnerability, showing divine justice at work.

verses.text: The hungry eat his harvest, taking it even from among thorns, and the thirsty swallow their wealth.
verses.comment: Symbolically speaks of loss of blessings reserved for the righteous, supporting the theme of divine recompense.

verses.text: For hardship does not spring from the dust, nor does trouble grow out of the ground;
verses.comment: Emphasizes human moral responsibility; suffering is not random, but has a deeper origin.

verses.text: Yet man is born to trouble, as surely as sparks fly upward.
verses.comment: References original sin and universal suffering. Anticipates the need for redemption, a recurrent biblical theme.

verses.text: But as for me, I would seek God, and to God I would present my case.
verses.comment: Model of seeking God—mirrored in later teaching about prayer and intercession.

verses.text: He does great and unsearchable things, wonders without number.
verses.comment: Affirms divine mystery and sovereignty. Directs attention to God's providence and miraculous works.

verses.text: He gives rain on the earth, and sends water on the fields.
verses.comment: Portrays God as the sustainer, providing for creation—foreshadows sacramental aspects of divine grace.

verses.text: He raises the lowly up, and lifts those who mourn to safety.
verses.comment: Connects to Christ's teaching about blessings for the poor and mourning; spiritual reversal of fortunes.

verses.text: He frustrates the plans of the crafty, so that their hands cannot carry out their schemes.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over human schemes underlines the futility of opposing divine wisdom.

verses.text: He catches the wise in their own deceit, and the plans of the cunning are quickly overturned.
verses.comment: Quoted in 1 Corinthians 3:19, showing continuity in God's approach from Old to New Testament.

verses.text: By day they stumble in darkness, and at noon they grope as if it were night.
verses.comment: Spiritual darkness is a theme developed in the prophets and fulfilled in Christ, the light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: But He saves the needy from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
verses.comment: God's protection is assured for the oppressed—prefigures Christ's defense of the vulnerable.

verses.text: So the poor have hope, and injustice shuts its mouth.
verses.comment: Justice and hope for the poor are central in Wisdom literature and later in Christ's ministry.

verses.text: Blessed is the one whom God corrects; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
verses.comment: Foreshadows NT teaching on divine discipline (see Hebrews 12:6); discipline is for sonship and spiritual growth.

verses.text: For He wounds, but He also binds up; He strikes, but His hands heal.
verses.comment: God’s chastisement is restorative—echoes later prophetic and New Testament themes of healing and restoration.

verses.text: From six calamities He will deliver you; in seven, no harm will touch you.
verses.comment: The numbers symbolize completeness and assured deliverance—anticipating themes of ultimate perseverance.

verses.text: In famine He will redeem you from death, and in war from the power of the sword.
verses.comment: Consistent with the greater promise of redemption—for physical and spiritual salvation.

verses.text: You will be shielded from the lash of the tongue, and you will not fear destruction when it comes.
verses.comment: Protection from slander and disaster remains a divine promise for the faithful.

verses.text: You will laugh at destruction and famine, and not be afraid of the wild beasts of the earth.
verses.comment: Fearlessness is a sign of trust and hope—found most perfectly in unity with Christ.

verses.text: For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
verses.comment: Hints at peace with creation—echoes themes of harmony and restoration associated with the fullness of redemption.

verses.text: You will know that your tent is secure, and you will inspect your home without fear of loss.
verses.comment: Blessing upon household and security as a result of faithfulness—reflects biblical values of order and stewardship.

verses.text: You will know that your descendants will be many, and your offspring as the grass of the earth.
verses.comment: The blessing of abundant progeny recalls Abrahamic promises and the importance of legacy in the faith.

verses.text: You will come to the grave in full strength, like a sheaf gathered in its season.
verses.comment: Death is seen as a timely harvest; alludes to hope of a fruitful, peaceful end.

verses.text: Look, we have examined all this, and it is true. Hear it, and apply it to yourself.
verses.comment: Marks the conclusion of Eliphaz's argument. Encourages humility and openness to correction, which is echoed in both Old and New Testament wisdom tradition. Subtly implies importance of receiving spiritual instruction from those entrusted with interpreting God’s word.
